content:
re : I appreciate that the All Mail folder keeps emails even after they have been deleted from the Inbox

That depends on how you are using the 'Delete'. But in general I would say that is not the normal expectation.

All emails are stored in 'All Mail' In an Imap account : If you delete an email and have it auto put into the gmail Trash folder then gmail will auto delete emails older than 30 days from Trash and also auto delete them from 'All Mail'.

If you do not auto put deleted mail into gmail Trash, you are in effect by-passing the gmail TRash, then gmail understands that to mean 'Do not Delete email' just delete the 'label' and then Archive the email in 'All Mail'. So you still have it - it just does not have any labels attached to it.

In 'Account Settings' > 'Server Settings' for gmail account 'When I delete a message' To put email you delete into the gmail Trash: 'Move it to this folder Select 'Trash on gmail email address' In my case gmail have called the Trash folder 'Bin' - seems some brits have a 'Bin' as 'Trash'

But What option have you got selected ? It's important we understand what you have got set up.

Also how do you delete ? What buttons or icons or keyboard keys do you use ? Just wondering if you are deliberately using 'Shift'+'Del'.

If things are reappearing and you have an issue with 'All Mail', then it sounds like this may be due to a lack of compacting. But regardless there may be some corruption. The 'Inbox', 'Drafts' and 'Spam' usually get the most activity when it comes to moving or deleting emails, so those 3 folders should get compacted on a regualr basis. Personally, I do it every day before exiting Thunderbird. But in your case you also have the 'All Mail' and that means usually it also needs compacting because it has everything. But in this instance, do not compact 'All Mail'.

under 'Message Storage' Select 'Clean up (Expunge) Inbox on Exit'

This then auto compacts the Inbox on exit cleaning up all the old traces of moved or deleted emails. This is good housekeeping and helps to maintain a healthy mbox file. But please remember to not exit/close down computer too quickly as Thunderbird will be performing background processes. The alternative would be to not set the auto expunge/compact, but remember to do it manually before exiting, so you can be sure it has finished before you close Thunderbird.

Basically 'All Mail' is a massive file as it contains everything - incoming, saved in other folders, junk/spam, outgoing, archived - everything all in one place. Basically, it just means you have a complete duplicate - two of everything in one account.

Normally, I would advise people not to subscribe to the 'All Mail' because it's just a duplicate and uses up space on C: drive and in Thunderbird, it can be an enormous mbox file. That means every single email is in one single text document. If it should get corrupted, it may effect every email you have in any folder. If you have Anti-Virus installed as is the case with Windows OS (I note you are on Linux) then it can try to auto fix any files it does not like and this may result in a complete loss of emails. Even if you do not have an Anti-Virus performing anything, that 'All Mail' folder needs regular compacting. That means recreating a second copy that just contains emails not marked as deleted, so that's another copy before the original is deleted. You do not want any corruption occuring with that mbox file.

If you directly delete any email from the 'All Mail' folder then it gets auto deleted from Inbox or any imap folder.

DO THIS: I would advise you to 'unsubscribe' from seeing that 'All Mail' folder because it's too risky to compact it.

Then restart Thunderbird so it just removes the 'All Mail' data. Manually compact the 'Inbox', 'Drafts' and 'Spam'. Right click on folder and select 'Compact' Do each folder in turn.


re : Thunderbird 115.16.0esr (64-bit) Is there any reason why you have not updated to a newer version of Thunderbird ?

content:
re : I have enabled the Thunderbird dark mode.

I'm assuming you use Windows OS. What computer setting have you set up for apps ?

  • In Windows search type: Settings
  • Select 'Settings'
  • Select 'Personalisation'
  • Select 'Colours'

'Choose your colour'

  • click on the drop down and select 'Custom'

'Choose your default app mode'

  • Select 'Dark'

You should see an example at the top of that window and it should show 'Sample Text' using white font on dark background.

Where it says 'Choose your accent colour' Whatever colour you choose may get used for titles and buttons in Thunderbird depending upon some settings.

Confirm you have the 'dark' settings for apps.

content:
In Thunderbird

Click on the menu app icon (3 lines) select 'Addons & Themes' Select 'Themes' By default there will be 'System theme', 'Light' and 'Dark' You have selected 'Dark'

Have you installed another theme ? If yes, you need to remove any theme you have installed. It's not enough to be disabled. Please click on the 3 dot icon on the right side of the theme and select 'Remove' Then exit Thunderbird. Wait a few moments for background processes to complete and then restart Thunderbird.

The problem happens in the following views: Table View in Thunderbird 128, in particular to saved searches, but also to some standard folders. (no matter if Windows 10 or Windows 11)

It also happens in Troubleshoot mode without add-ons. Moreover the black font to dark background also applies to tags, however here the background is not so dark as in the message list, hence it is barely readable. It does not happen: to cards view. creator: h.it

content:
Finally I found out the solution.

The black font on dark background during dark mode was caused by a message filter that assigned a tag with a black font color Messages without a tag correctly obtained a white color. Changing the color of the tags fixes the issue.


One should choose a color that is visible in both day and night mode and this is sometimes difficult.

content:
The image shows the folder you cannot delete, but it does not show if that folder is in the 'Local Folders' account or whether it is in an imap or pop account.

How to tell if you have IMAP or POP or whether POP is set up as a deferred / Global Inbox account. In 'Account Settings' Select 'Server Settings' for account On the right side, at the top, locate 'Server Type' and it will say either 'IMAP Mail Server' or 'POP Mail Server'.

Do you have IMAP or POP ? Please let me know.

IF you have 'IMAP Mail Server' How to get rid of folder:

  • In Folder Pane
  • Right click on the name of the imap account folder and select 'Subscribe'
  • Select name of folder you want to delete and click on 'Unsubscribe'
  • Click on 'OK'

Then access webmail account via a browser and delete the Измерительные Технологи folders off server.

IF POP:

  • How to check whether it is a normal POP account using it's own folders OR a deferred account set up to use a Global Inbox.

'Server Settings' for account - on the right - click on 'Advanced' button

If you have selected the first option 'Inbox for this account' This is a normal POP account set up to use it's own set of folders in the Folder Pane.

If you have selected 'Inbox for different account' Then you probably selected 'Global Inbox (Local Folders)' This is a deferred account. It uses 'Local Folders' account. In Folder Pane, you will not see the Pop account as a separate account. You will notice the 'Local Folders' account Inbox gets all the Pop account incoming mail.

content:
Thanks for information and image.

Try this direct method. In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' about half-way is 'Profile Folder' - click on 'Open Folder' button - see image as guide.

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now - this is important.
  • Double Click on 'Mail' folder to see contents.
  • Double Click on 'Local Folders' folder to see contents.
  • Double click on the folder called 'Suppliers.sbd'
  • Delete 'Измерительные Технологии' mbox file (no extension)
  • Delete 'Измерительные Технологии.msf' index file.

Restart Thunderbird.

content:
Bu durumda SMTP sunucularınızı kontrol edelim.

Menü > Hesap ayarlarına girin. Sol taraftan Giden sunucusu (SMTP) ekranına girin. Burada iki ayrı hesabınız için iki ayrı sunucu görüyor olmalısınız. Ayarları aynı ama kullanıcı adları farklı olmalı.

İlkini seçip Düzenle'ye tıklayın. Kullanıcı adı alanında gördüğünüz e-posta adresini Tanım alanına da yazın. Aynı işlemi diğer sunucu için de yapın. Bu sayede az sonra yapacağımız işlemde bu sunucuları birbirinden ayırt edebileceğiz.

Şimdi sol taraftan cigdem.cengiz@... şeklindeki hesabınızı seçin. Ekranın en altındaki Giden sunucusu (SMTP) ayarını kontrol edin. Doğru e-posta adresine ait doğru sunucu seçilmiş görünüyor mu? Doğru değilse doğrusunu seçin.

content:
Oi! Para diagnosticar problemas com o Thunderbird, tente uma das seguintes opções:

  • Reinicie o Thunderbird com os complementos desabilitados (Modo Thunderbird Seguro). No menu Ajuda, clique em "Reiniciar com os complementos desativados". Se o Thunderbird funciona normal, há um problema com algum complemento ou tema. Você vai precisar reativar os complementos, um de cada vez, até localizar o infrator.
  • Reinicie o sistema operacional em modo de segurança com rede. Isso carrega apenas o básico necessário para iniciar o computador, permitindo uma ligação à Internet. Clique no seu sistema operacional para obter instruções sobre como iniciar em modo de segurança: Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows XP, OSX
Se o modo de segurança do sistema operacional corrige o problema, há outro software em seu computador que está causando problemas. As possibilidades incluem, mas não limitados: a digitalização AV, vírus / malwares, downloads em segundo plano, como atualizações do programa.

Se mesmo assim o problema persistir, entre em contato com ZOHO para obter suporte sobre os servidores deles.

content:
Una considerazione: se stai usando IMAP non c'è alcun bisogno di impostare il salvataggio sul server. È il protocollo stesso che dovrebbe garantire la copia sul server delle email inviate. Per cui mi sfugge la necessità di questo settaggio.

Per il resto purtroppo sei incappato in un tipo di errore abbastanza rognoso, come puoi leggere ad esempio in queste discussioni: - https://forum.mozillaitalia.org/index.php?topic=74077.15 - https://forum.mozillaitalia.org/index.php?topic=77266.0 - https://forum.mozillaitalia.org/index.php?topic=72671.0

Io ti suggerisco di impostare la copia su una cartella locale come descritto qui -> https://www.ino.cnr.it/bl/?p=144

se però non puoi modificare quella impostazione o comunque il cambio di cartella non funziona, probabilmente fai prima a ripartire da zero con la configurazione di un nuovo profilo.
creator: @next

content:
Purtroppo il protocollo non funziona, cioè le mail inviate non andavano nella cartella sul server per cui ho provato vari opzioni.

Pero ora, ho già impostato sulla cartella locale, ma usando il client su più postazioni in luoghi diversi volevo tenere tutto sincronizzato.

Sono anche ripartito da zero, cancellando tutto, disinstallando il programma e reinstallando tutto con nuovi impostazioni senza importare nulla, ma non è cambiato l'errore.

Grazie dell'aiuto e sei sggerimenti
creator: marcotrasacco

content:
IMAP serve proprio a sincronizzare tutto e nel 99% dei casi non ha bisogno di configurazione particolare. Nel tuo caso però potrebbe essere necessario verificare che la cartella in cui finisce la posta inviata si tra quelle selezionate per la sincronizzazione -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/sincronizzazione-imap#w_configurazione-della-sincronizzazione-ed-utilizzo-dello-spazio-sul-disco

Potresti anche provare a copiare la posta inviata in una cartella locale diversa da quella predefinita, magari creata appositamente. E poi fare il controllo di cui sopra.
creator: @next

content: Thunderbird from MS is a different animal, in that it stores in a different location and some features of thunderbird for troubleshooting do not work. I 'think' the profile is in appdata\local.
creator: davidsk

content:
I found another post with the same question and says that the profile and other app data on the Microsoft Store version is located in:

C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\packages\MozillaThunderbird.MZLA_h5892qc0xkpca

When I mouse to that location - there it is! (Right down to the strange "MZLA..." directory name.

I think I'm going to uninstall the MS Store version, and reinstall with the downloaded installer... What a pain!

And thanks to david a Top 10 Contributor, who put me on the right track:

"Thunderbird from MS is a different animal, in that it stores in a different location and some features of thunderbird for troubleshooting do not work. I 'think' the profile is in appdata\local."
creator: That60sKid

content: I was glad to assist. And, I agree that switching to the mozilla version is a good move, especially if/when you need help. :)
creator: davidsk

content: Related to https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1457319 ?
creator: wsmwk

content: I don't see the relation/connection. Any other ideas?
creator: mwrr

content:
Are they IMAP or POP accounts?

IMAP accounts use server folders, not local folders. If you want messages from IMAP accounts to go to local folders, you will have to create filters.

I assume that you could also set up those accounts as POP accounts, but I do not know because I have not used a POP account in about 25 years.
creator: user213815874572776100201782415079883066567

content: okay, if you prefer to combine browser and email, the Seamonkey is your best choice. Regarding email, yes, you must first have established an email account with a third party and then go through the setup process to add the account to your email client, whether Thunderbird or Seamonkey.
creator: davidsk
